awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Physics and Astronomy at the University of Toledo
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the funding of the REU site in Physics and Astronomy at the University of Toledo. Undergraduate students have a variety of cutting edge research opportunities in topics: Astrophysics; Atomic/Molecular/Optical Physics; Biological/Health/Medical Physics; Condensed Matter/Materials; Computational Physics; (with specialization in thin films and photovoltaics); and Plasma Physics. Opportunities exist for some of the research projects to be conducted with their faculty mentors at national facilities. The research projects are chosen such that they will lead to eventual publication in the appropriate professional research journals.  REU students will be involved in exciting research in a department that allows individualized attention yet is large enough to give students experiences in a variety of physics subfields. A variety of social activities for the REU students are also planned. The REU site is committed to involving students from diverse backgrounds in this research experience. A majority of tracked former REU students have successfully gone onto graduate school for an M.S. or Ph.D. in physics, astronomy, and related areas. This program contributes to the generation of the STEM workforce in the US.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Toledo's NSF REU program in Physics and Astronomy, under the leadership of Dr. Richard Irving and Professor Sanjay V. Khare, has demonstrated substantial success and impact with its 2022 and 2023 cohorts. This report outlines the program's outcomes and findings, emphasizing both its intellectual merit and broader impacts.

Intellectual Merit 

Research Opportunities and Achievements:

The 2022 program engaged 8 undergraduate students from 5 colleges across 4 states, while the 2023 cohort included 10 students from 10 colleges in 7 states. Students from both cohorts made significant academic contributions, evidenced by co-authorship in peer-reviewed publications and active participation in prestigious conferences like CUWiP and IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference. The research topics were diverse and impactful, ranging from astrophysics and biophysics to material science and solar cell technology, demonstrating the program's commitment to cutting-edge research in Physics and Astronomy.

Educational Enhancement:

The program’s success in nurturing future scientists is highlighted by former participants like R. J. Nelson (2021 cohort) and B. Dokken (2022 cohort), who achieved notable research success. The integration of modern computational tools in the curriculum, through workshops on Python, Latex, and Overleaf, significantly enhanced the participants' research capabilities.

Broader Impacts 

Diversity and Inclusion:

The cohorts were remarkably diverse, with the majority of participants in 2022 and 2023 being women and minorities, respectively, showcasing the program’s commitment to broadening participation in STEM fields.

Community and Networking:

The collaborative living arrangements in the International House and Parks Tower dormitories facilitated a community-centric experience, promoting interdisciplinary interactions and networking. Visits to First Solar and the Toledo Museum of Art illustrated the practical applications of physics, expanding students' understanding of career opportunities beyond academia. Social activities included visits to sites where physics research is being applied including industrial, and cultural visits, fostered a well-rounded experience, contributing to the broader development of participants.

Professional Development:

Workshops and seminars focused on career development and research skills, enhancing students' readiness for future academic and professional pursuits were provided. Opportunities for presenting research at seminars and conferences, along with mentorship from faculty, provided invaluable experience in scientific communication and networking.

Mentorship and Training:

Faculty mentors, benefiting from APS-PRTS workshops and regular interactions with the program directors, were well-equipped to guide students effectively. The program's alignment with APS-PRTS standards ensured high-quality mentorship, crucial for the students' research experience and professional growth.

Sustainability and Long-term Impact:

The program's success is further evidenced by the continuous tracking of alumni and the implementation of CIMER Common Assessment Surveys for objective program evaluation. The alumni network and ongoing mentorship opportunities extend the program's impact beyond the summer, contributing to the participants' long-term professional development.

 

In summary, the University of Toledo's NSF REU program in Physics and Astronomy has not only achieved significant intellectual merit through high-quality research and education but also made broader impacts by fostering diversity, community building, and professional development. The program's comprehensive approach to scientific training and its commitment to creating an inclusive and collaborative environment have significantly contributed to preparing the next generation of scientists.
